messageBody:
> You are right. We should only test a Unit instead of testing the
> unit, the framework, the application server and the database.

I'm testing with databases right now and it's in fact very tricky. I'm not
using mock objects and directly test with the database. The reason is that I
test a database access layer, so I really need to test with the databases I support.

I believe that you have to test with the database anyway so I would at least
have some integration tests that are using the databases directly.

On the side note, I've made an *alpha* release of the TestRunner I currently use
for my integration tests. There is no documentation and it's released *as is*
so if you like to live dangerously, you can try it out.

> I suggested to use mock objects and Test Driven Development. But the
> senior programers don't want it. I listed all the many advantages
> but couldn't convince them.

I would first present JUnit and set up Continuous Integration (or a nightly
build). Once the developers are more confident in their tests, you can
introduce TDD. I don't think that TDD is a requirement for good software.
Tests definitively are.

I would also introduce Eclipse/PMD and check out the errors in the code.

-Vladimir
